inscription: Near here stood the first three plaisterers' Halls 1556 to 1940
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: Several halls of the Plaisterers� Company once stood nearby, each lost to the Great Fire or later bomb damage. Members specialised in plaster finishes, mouldings and decorative ceilings for houses, churches and public buildings. The current modern hall nearby continues their traditions of craft awards and charity, while the plaque acknowledges a long sequence of buildings that physically hosted the company�s activities in this part of the City.

title: Duke of Buckinghams House
inscription: Site of The Duke of Buckingham's House 1672
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: This plaque marks the site of a townhouse occupied at various times by the Dukes of Buckingham, powerful nobles entangled in court politics and royal favour. Like other aristocratic residences in the City, it placed elite families within walking distance of the river stairs and royal palaces. Later redevelopment erased the building, but the marker recalls a period when College Hill mixed great merchants, civic officials and high-ranking courtiers.

title: Turners' Hall, Second
inscription: On or Near This Site Stood The Second Turners' Hall 1736-66
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: The Turners� Company represented wood-turners who produced bowls, chair legs, balusters and other rounded items. Their second hall here replaced earlier quarters lost to disaster and provided space for meetings, dinners and craft governance. As handmade woodware gradually declined in industrial times, the company shifted toward charity, but the plaque preserves memory of their physical base in the riverside mercantile quarter.

title: Richard Whittington House
inscription: The House of Richard Whittington Mayor of London Stood on this Site 1423
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: Richard Whittington, the wealthy mercer and four-time Lord Mayor, endowed almshouses and public works, including drainage improvements and a ward for unmarried mothers at St Thomas�s Hospital. A house on this site has long been associated with him. The plaque ties the folk-tale of �Dick Whittington� to a real merchant whose fortune and philanthropy left lasting marks on London�s infrastructure and institutions.

title: St Thomas A Becket
inscription: St Thomas A Becket Was Born in a House Near this Spot
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: Here stood a church dedicated to St Thomas Becket, whose martyrdom became a powerful symbol of resistance to royal interference in the Church. Serving traders along Cheapside, the building was lost through fire and later rebuilding. The plaque preserves its dedication, hinting at the dense cluster of shrines and altars that once anchored religious and commercial life along this main market street.

title: The Great Conduit
inscription: The Great Conduit Stood in this Street Providing Free Water 13th Century to 1666
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: The Great Conduit brought fresh water from springs at Tyburn to a central reservoir, feeding public taps along Cheapside from the 13th century onward. On ceremonial occasions wine sometimes flowed through its pipes for the crowd. Repeatedly repaired and eventually replaced by modern supply systems, it was vital civic infrastructure in a crowded city dependent on clean water; the plaque fixes its location in front of a modern supermarket.

title: Cutlers' Hall
inscription: Site of Cutlers' Hall 1416-1883 Rebuilt After the Great Fire 1666
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: Cutlers� Hall housed the Worshipful Company of Cutlers, who oversaw the making and selling of knives, scissors and surgical instruments. They enforced standards and marked blades, while also providing charity for members. As Sheffield rose, London�s cutlers lost dominance but retained ceremonial functions. The plaque shows where their hall once stood in the riverward commercial district close to wharves and metal merchants.

title: Joiners & Ceilers Hall
inscription: Site of the Hall of the Worshipful Company of Joiners and Ceilers 1603-1796
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: The Joiners and Ceilers� hall overlooked the busy Thames, convenient for timber deliveries. Members installed panelled rooms, staircases and ornate ceilings in houses and public buildings. Fires and bombing eventually destroyed their premises, and the riverside has been reshaped into wharves and offices, but the plaque signals where skilled woodworkers once organised training, standards and charitable funds for their trade.

title: Benjamin Disraeli
inscription: Benjamin Disraeli Prime Minister in 1868 and 1874-1880 Worked in this Building 1821-1824
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: Benjamin Disraeli briefly worked as a solicitor�s clerk at Frederick�s Place before his political and literary fame. He later became Conservative leader, novelist and twice Prime Minister, associated with imperial policy and social reforms such as the Artisans� and Labourers� Dwellings Act. The plaque ties this quiet courtyard to the very start of a flamboyant career that would end in the House of Lords as Earl of Beaconsfield.

title: Edwin Waterhouse
inscription: Edwin Waterhouse Eminent Accountant Worked in this Building 1899-1905
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: Edwin Waterhouse co-founded the accountancy partnership Price, Waterhouse, Peirce & Co, which evolved into Price Waterhouse and later PwC. From offices in Frederick�s Place, the firm developed modern auditing practices for railways, banks and industrial companies. The plaque links this discreet address with the professionalisation of accountancy, an essential underpinning of Victorian and modern corporate finance.

title: St Mary Cole Church
inscription: Site of St Mary Cole Church Destroyed in the Great Fire 1666
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: St Mary Cole was a tiny parish church squeezed among merchants� houses and counting-houses in Old Jewry. Damaged in the Great Fire and later demolished, its parish was absorbed elsewhere. Its footprint is difficult to trace in today�s street pattern; the plaque is one of the few hints that an active worshipping community once gathered here in the heart of the financial district.

title: Great Synagogue
inscription: The Great Synagogue Stood near this site until 1272
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: This plaque recalls an early Ashkenazi synagogue in Old Jewry, predating the later Great Synagogue in Dukes Place. It served a growing Jewish community after formal readmission under Cromwell. Traders and craftsmen worshipped here, and the surrounding lanes housed kosher butchers and communal institutions. Although nothing of the building survives, the marker records a key stage in the re-establishment of Jewish religious life in the City.

title: Thomas Hood
inscription: In a House on this Site Thomas Hood was Born 23rd May 1799
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: Poet and humorist Thomas Hood worked in this area as an engraver and later editor of Punch. His poem �The Song of the Shirt� drew attention to the misery of exploited seamstresses, while other verses played with puns and comic imagery. The plaque connects the bustle of Poultry, once lined with banks and drapers, to a writer whose work spanned both sharp social protest and light magazine verse.

title: St Stephen Parish Church
inscription: Site of the Parish Church of St Stephen Coleman Street 1452-1940
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: St Stephen Coleman Street was known for its Puritan congregation and politically active ministers in the 17th century. Some parishioners supported Parliament during the Civil War, and the church became associated with dissent. Bomb damage in the Second World War led to its demolition and union of parishes. The plaque ensures that its reputation as a centre of nonconformist worship is not entirely obscured by later office blocks.

title: Samaritans
inscription: In St Stephen Walbrook on 2 Novemebr 1953 The samaritans were founded by Dr. Chad Varah rector 1953-2003
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: In 1953 the rector of St Stephen Walbrook, Chad Varah, founded the Samaritans here, offering a confidential telephone service for people in distress and at risk of suicide. Starting with a single telephone in the crypt, the charity became a nationwide and then international organisation. The plaque marks both the birthplace of a new model of emotional support and the continuing use of a City church as a place of listening and care.

title: Mary Harris Smith
inscription: Near this site stood the office of Mary Harris Smith FCA the world's first female chartered accountatn 1844-1934
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: Mary Harris Smith campaigned for years to be admitted as a chartered accountant, repeatedly refused because of her sex. In 1920, late in life, she was finally accepted by the Society of Incorporated Accountants, making her arguably the world�s first female chartered accountant. Working from premises near Bucklersbury, she ran her own practice; the plaque honours both her persistence and a breakthrough in professional equality.

title: Sir Ebeneezer Howard
inscription: Near this spot at 62 Fore Street on the 29th January 1850 was born Sir Ebenezer Howard Founder of the Garden City Movement
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: Ebenezer Howard, a shorthand writer turned social thinker, proposed Garden Cities blending town and country in his 1898 book Tomorrow: A Peaceful Path to Real Reform. From London offices he promoted model settlements that produced Letchworth and Welwyn. The plaque by London Wall ties modern office towers to the roots of British town planning and a worldwide movement for healthier, planned communities.

title: Founders' Hall
inscription: In this court stood Founder's Hall 1531-1845 rebuilt after the great fire 1666
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: The Founders� Company represented craftsmen who cast metal objects such as bells, candlesticks, weights and hardware. Their hall near the Bank of England placed them at the centre of the financial and metal trades. Over time, industrial change reduced small workshops in the City, but the company maintained charitable and ceremonial functions. The plaque signals where furnaces and moulds once stood in a lane now dominated by banking.

title: General Letter Office
inscription: Near this spot the General Letter Office stood in Post house Yard 1653-166 Here were struck in 1661 the first postmarks in the world (AP/19)
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: Before the vast General Post Office rose in St Martin�s-le-Grand, the General Letter Office here managed incoming and outgoing mail for London and the provinces. Clerks sorted letters by hand, and mail coaches departed under strict schedules. The plaque reminds us that systematic postal services�so central to trade, administration and personal life�were built from modest, crowded offices like this one at the City�s core.

title: John Keats
inscription: In a House on this site the "Swan & Hoop" John Keats Poet was born 1795
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: At premises in Moorgate, John Keats served his apprenticeship to a surgeon�apothecary before continuing medical studies at Guy�s Hospital. He passed exams to practise, but soon abandoned medicine for poetry. The plaque underscores that his intense, short literary career grew from a background of dissecting rooms, dressings and apothecary�s jars in the City�s medical quarter.

title: Charles Brooking
inscription: Charles Brooking 1723-1759 Marine painter lived near this site
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: Marine painter Charles Brooking specialised in detailed ship portraits and harbour scenes in the mid-18th century. His works are valued both artistically and as visual records of warships, merchantmen and coastal traffic. The plaque places his home or studio close to the Bank of England, emphasising that fine maritime art was produced in cramped City streets rather than only in grand academies.

title: St Martin Orgar
inscription: Site of St Martin Orgar Church
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: St Martin Orgar was a tiny church near Cannon Street, partly used after the Great Fire by a French Protestant congregation. Its tower lingered as a landmark long after the nave disappeared, before final clearance. The plaque fixes its approximate position, showing how foreign congregations adapted surviving fragments of City churches as they sought worship space amid dense commercial streets.

title: Gregory de Rokesley
inscription: In a house on this site lived Gregory de Rokesley eight times Mayor of London 1274-1281 and 1285
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: Gregory de Rokesley, a 13th-century goldsmith and multiple-term Lord Mayor of London, lived or worked near Lombard Street, long associated with bankers and money-changers. He acted as royal assay master for coinage and wielded significant influence in civic politics. The plaque anchors his story in a street still tied to finance, linking medieval municipal leadership with today�s banking district.

title: Lloyd's Coffee House
inscription: Site of Lloyd's Coffee House 1691-1785
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: Lloyd�s Coffee House began as one of many City coffee houses but specialised in shipping news, attracting merchants and captains. Handwritten lists of ships� movements evolved into systematic records of risks and losses. From these informal sheets grew Lloyd�s of London, now a leading insurance market. The plaque marks the modest starting point of a global institution rooted in maritime trade and gossip over cups of coffee.

title: King William Street Underground Station
inscription: Site of King William Street underground station first City Terminus 1890-1900
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: Opened in 1890 as part of the City and South London Railway, King William Street was the line�s original City terminus and the first deep-level tube station in the world. Awkwardly sited and sharply curved, it closed when new tunnels diverted the route. Hidden platforms and passages still exist below ground; the plaque above records a pioneering moment in London�s move to electric underground travel.

title: First Coffee House
inscription: Here Stood the First London Coffee House at the sign of Pasqua Rosee's Head 1652
address: 4 St Michael's Alley (Jamaica Coffee House), EC3V 9DS
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: St Michael�s Alley is traditionally cited as the location of one of London�s earliest coffee houses, opened in the 1650s. Merchants met here to talk trade, ships and politics over exotic, bitter coffee, a novelty at the time. This culture spawned specialist houses for stockbrokers, insurers and writers. The plaque at the Jamaica Wine House (on the same site) recalls the drink that helped reshape City business and sociability.

title: St Leonard Eastcheap
inscription: Site of St Leonard Eastcheap destroyed in the Great Fire 1666
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: The church of St Leonard Eastcheap served butchers and traders in this busy market street, its tower standing among signs and stalls. Destroyed in the Great Fire and not rebuilt, its parish was united with St Benet Gracechurch. The plaque restores the name of a parish otherwise lost beneath Victorian office blocks, hinting at the religious life that once paralleled noisy commerce below.

title: William Curtis
inscription: In a house on this site lived William Curtis Botanist B.1746 - D.1799
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: Botanist William Curtis ran a seed and plant business in Gracechurch Street while working on Flora Londinensis, a lavish work illustrating plants found around London. He later founded the Botanical Magazine, which continues today. The plaque links a former shopfront to the origins of popular botany and horticultural publishing, showing how scientific curiosity flourished in the middle of the commercial City.

title: Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI)
inscription: Site of the first headquarters of the Royal National Lifeboat Institution 1824-1826
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: This plaque marks an early London office of the RNLI, the charity that runs lifeboats around Britain and Ireland�s coasts. Fundraising, administration and public appeals were coordinated from sites like this in the City, far from the sea. It underlines how urban philanthropy and City donors kept lifeboat crews supplied with boats, gear and training to save lives in storms and shipwrecks.

title: St Benet Gracechurch
inscription: Site of St Benet Gracechurch Demolished 1876
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: St Benet Gracechurch was a Wren-rebuilt church standing at the junction of Gracechurch Street and Fenchurch Street, serving a parish of traders and residents. Declining congregations led to its demolition in the 19th century, with the site used for road widening. The plaque fixes its position in the traffic flow, reminding us that church towers once punctuated what is now a canyon of offices and shops.

title: St Mary Moorfields
inscription: Site of St Mary Moorfields Pro Cathedral of the Roman Catholic Church 1852-1870
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: St Mary Moorfields, once near here, became the first purpose-built Catholic parish church in London after emancipation in the early 19th century. It served a scattered Catholic population before moving and ultimately being replaced by a modern building further north. The plaque highlights the cautious return of open Catholic worship in the City after centuries of restrictions.

title: St Dionis Backchurch
inscription: Site of St Dionis backchurch demolished 1878
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: St Dionis Backchurch, rebuilt by Wren after the Great Fire, stood set back from Fenchurch Street until its demolition in the 19th century. Its parish was united with All Hallows Lombard Street, and a successor church was later built in Parsons Green. The plaque notes its former footprint among insurance offices and brokerages, linking modern commerce to a long ecclesiastical presence.

title: Bethlehem Hospital First
inscription: Site of the First Bethlehem Hospital 1247-1676
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: Bethlem Hospital, founded in the 13th century as a priory infirmary, moved to a site near here in the 17th century before shifting again to Moorfields and later Beckenham. Notorious as �Bedlam�, it drew sightseers and became a symbol of chaos and cruelty. The plaque marks its earliest City location and invites reflection on how treatment of mental illness has changed since those brutal, overcrowded wards.

title: Parish Clerks' First Hall
inscription: On this site until the mid sixteenth century stood the first hall of the Parish Clerks' Company
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: The Parish Clerks� first hall stood close to this lane, from which they coordinated duties across dozens of parishes: reading banns, announcing funerals, keeping registers and leading processions. As literate laymen, clerks also provided information to early statisticians and public health officials. Subsequent halls relocated as the City changed, but this marker points to their original corporate home in a tightly packed web of alleys.

title: St Mary Axe church
inscription: Site of St Mary Axe Church 1230-1561
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: The medieval church of St Mary Axe gave its name to the narrow street but disappeared long ago, its parish merged with others. Only documents and this plaque attest to its existence. The street name later lent itself to modern landmarks like the Gherkin at 30 St Mary Axe, so the marker quietly connects today�s glass towers back to a lost parish church and its small congregation.

title: Samuel Pepys (Navy Office)
inscription: Site of the Navy Office in which Samuel Pepys lived and worked destroyed by fire 1673
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: The Navy Office complex on Seething Lane housed Samuel Pepys during his years as Clerk of the Acts and later Secretary to the Admiralty. From offices here he oversaw shipbuilding, victualling and pay, while recording daily life in his diary. Destroyed in the Great Fire and later rebuilt, the site is now a garden. The plaque fixes the administrative heart of the Restoration navy in a quiet corner by the Tower.

title: Tylers & Bricklayers Hall
inscription: On this site stood Tylers' and Bricklayers' Hall 1538-1883
organisations: City of London
lead_subject_bio: The Tylers and Bricklayers� hall near Leadenhall Street represented builders responsible for roof tiling, brickwork and plastering�essential trades in an expanding metropolis. From here the company regulated apprenticeships and workmanship, and later turned to charitable work for members. The plaque notes where their hall stood before redevelopment, reminding today�s office workers that the City once rang with the sound of building trades on these very plots.
